coredata.dc:title: Lithophilic secondary structure enables robust solid electrolyte interface for highly stable lithium metal battery

coredata.dc:description: The 3D substrates with large specific surface area which can reduce the volume change of anodes have been used to realize stable lithium metal batteries (LMBs). However, the capacity and long-term stability of LMBs are hampered by the growth of lithium dendrites and side reactions of the electrode-electrolyte interface, which are still unable to be addressed by the enlarged specific surface. In this study, CuO/Cu3N foam current collector with fiber secondary structure is constructed, where the increased active sites and lithophilic surface layer accelerate the kinetics of lithium transport, and the sturdy Li2O/Li3N solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is generated during the lithium plating, which effectively reduces the adverse side reactions and promotes the uniform deposition of Li. The symmetric cell of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li cycles stably for more than 1500 h and exhibits an outstanding cycle life of more than 500 h at high current density and capacity of 5 mA cm−2 and 5 mAh cm−2. And CuO/Cu3N foam@Li||LFP full cell exhibits an excellent cycling performance of 350 cycles with a high capacity retention rate of 78 %. This work provides valuable insights into the development of advanced current collectors for high-energy LMBs.

Current collector
Lithophilic Cu foam
Heterogeneous SEI

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: a) Schematic diagram of the synthesis process of CuO/Cu3N foam. Top view of SEM images of b) Cu foam, c) CuO foam and d) CuO/Cu3N foam. e) Cross-sectional SEM images, f-g) corresponding element mapping images and h) XRD spectra of CuO/Cu3N foam.

Depiction of the adsorption sites of Li atoms on a) Cu (111), CuO (111) and Cu3N (220) crystal planes, and b) their binding energies with Li+, respectively. XPS spectra of c) O 1 s and d) N 1 s of diffrent foam current collectors after lithium deposited. e) Schematic diagram of the deposition characteristics of Li on bare Cu, CuO and CuO/Cu3N foams. The orange, red, blue, and purple spheres represent Cu, O, N, and Li atoms, respectively.

a) Nucleation overpotential of Li deposited on Cu foam, CuO foam and CuO/Cu3N foam. b) Coulombic efficiency of half cells at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2. c) Voltage-capacity curves of the half cell of CuO/Cu3N foam for different cycles. Cycling performance of symmetric cells of Cu foam@Li, CuO foam@Li, and CuO/Cu3N foam@Li d) at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2 and e) at 5 mA cm−2 and 5 mAh cm−2. f) Rate performance evaluation of Cu foam@Li, CuO foam@Li, and CuO/Cu3N foam@Li when increase the current density and capacity from 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2 to 5 mA cm−2 and 5 mAh cm−2 gradually at the same time.

Top view and cross-sectional SEM images of a-c) Cu foam@Li, d-f) CuO foam@Li, and g-i) CuO/Cu3N foam@Li cycled for 10 cycles. XPS spectra of j) N 1 s and k) O 1 s of Cu foam@Li, CuO foam@Li and CuO/Cu3N foam@Li after 10 cycles. The current density distribution simulation in presence of lithium dendrite on l) Cu foam, m) CuO foam and n) CuO/Cu3N foam.

a) Charge/discharge performance of the different LFP full cells at 1 C, and the charge-discharge curves of the LFP full cells of b) CuO/Cu3N foam@Li, c) CuO foam@Li and d) Cu foam@Li at diffient cycles. e) The rate performance at different current densities. f) The cycling performance at 1 C of the different NCM811 full cells. g) The comparison of electrochemical properties with reported literatures.

head.ce:title: Lithophilic secondary structure enables robust solid electrolyte interface for highly stable lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Chemical & Environmental Engineering, China University of Mining & Technology (Beijing), Beijing 100083, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Chemical & Environmental Engineering, China University of Mining & Technology (Beijing)

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: School of Chemical & Environmental Engineering, China University of Mining & Technology (Beijing), Beijing, 100083, PR China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The 3D substrates with large specific surface area which can reduce the volume change of anodes have been used to realize stable lithium metal batteries (LMBs). However, the capacity and long-term stability of LMBs are hampered by the growth of lithium dendrites and side reactions of the electrode-electrolyte interface, which are still unable to be addressed by the enlarged specific surface. In this study, CuO/Cu3N foam current collector with fiber secondary structure is constructed, where the increased active sites and lithophilic surface layer accelerate the kinetics of lithium transport, and the sturdy Li2O/Li3N solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is generated during the lithium plating, which effectively reduces the adverse side reactions and promotes the uniform deposition of Li. The symmetric cell of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li cycles stably for more than 1500 h and exhibits an outstanding cycle life of more than 500 h at high current density and capacity of 5 mA cm−2 and 5 mAh cm−2. And CuO/Cu3N foam@Li||LFP full cell exhibits an excellent cycling performance of 350 cycles with a high capacity retention rate of 78 %. This work provides valuable insights into the development of advanced current collectors for high-energy LMBs.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: We report an CuO/Cu3N foam current collector with fiber secondary structure, where the increased active sites and lithophilic surface layer accelerate the kinetics of lithium transport, and the robust Li2O/Li3N solid electrolyte interface (SEI) is generated during the lithium plating, which effectively reduces the adverse side reactions and promotes the uniform deposition of Li.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium metal is the most promising anode material for the upcoming generation of high-energy-density batteries because of its lowest reduction potential (3.04 V vs. SHE) and maximum theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) [1–4]. However, when lithium metal comes into touch with the electrolyte, its extraordinarily high activity causes a redox reaction instantly, covering the surface with a passivation layer. This redox reaction will be more violent at impressed current, which means that loose and uneven solid electrolyte interface (SEI) will be formed on the surface of the lithium metal during the continuous plating/stripping process [3,5,6]. It is not conducive to the uniform deposition of lithium and allows the formation of dendrites, which will have a significant impact on the safety stability, reversibility, capacity retention, and coulombic efficiency of lithium metal batteries (LMBs) [7–10]. Therefore, adopting a simple and effective way to homogenize lithium deposition while attaining continuous cycling stability of LMBs at high current densities remains a formidable challenge.

The capacity and long-term stability of the LMBs are greatly impacted by the Cu current collector, an essential part that connects the anode material with the external circuit and the substrate of lithium deposition [11–13]. However, Cu has a poor lithophilicity and a small specific surface area, then the local current density on the surface of Cu foil rises, causing lithium dendrites to grow quickly and severely reducing the capacity of LMBs [14,15]. And due to the formation of lithium dendrites and the accumulation of byproducts during the plating/stripping of lithium metal, the anode will inevitably undergo some volume and compositional changes, and the cells will eventually fail during cycling, which is lethal for LMBs [16]. Therefore, accelerating the migration of lithium ions at the interface and guiding the uniform deposition of lithium are the key processes to regulate the operation of lithium metal anodes. Constructing 3D current collectors is a proven way to solve these problems. The generous spatial structure of 3D frame allows lithium to fill the interior, minimizing the volume change of the lithium metal anode during cycling [13,17,18]. Furthermore, the 3D structure can lower local current density and facilitate homogeneous lithium deposition due to its increased specific surface area [19–21]. According to the Sand’s time, the initial time of dendrite growth can be calculated by the equation,
(1)
τ = π D
C
0
e
2 J
t
a
2
where C
0 is the initial concentration of lithium salt, D is the diffusion coefficient, e is the elementary charge, t
a is the migration number of anions, and J is the current density [22,23]. Reducing the current density can effectively delay the initial growth time of lithium dendrites, thereby inhibiting their growth.

Although Cu foam has a 3D structure and good conductivity, [24,25] the poor lithophilicity and low space utilization rate still prevent it from being an ideal current collector of lithium metal anode [26]. Cu foams co-modified with nano Zn, Sn, and Cu10Sn3 were prepared, where the lithophilic and lithiophobic phases worked together to achieve homogeneous lithium deposition [27]. The construction of graphene scaffolds (GN@Cu) on Cu foams as lithophilic current collector has been reported to improve the cycling stability of LMBs in a wide current density range [28]. Using techniques including ion sputtering and atomic layer deposition, composite Cu foams modified with Au and ZnF2 were prepared, achieving highly stable coulombic efficiency and long term cycling for LMBs [29]. The aforementioned tactics addressed the issues of low lithophilicity and limited specific surface area of Cu foils, and offered helpful suggestions and direction for the modification of Cu foams. However, the above strategies have issues with complex experimental protocols and expensive raw materials, which make large-scale industrialized production still challenging in terms of overall experimental feasibility and cost-effectiveness ratio.

In this work, the Cu foam is oxidized in a mixed solution and then nitrided with urea to obtain a CuO/Cu3N foam with substructure of fibers on the surface, which increases the specific surface area. The 3D frame and secondary fiber structure increase the active sites for lithium deposition significantly, reducing the local current density and controlling the plating/stripping behavior of lithium. The lithophilic CuO/Cu3N surface layer can lower the nucleation overpotential of lithium, and form a robust Li2O/Li3N-rich SEI during cycling, which increases the conductivity of Li+ ions, and thus stabilizing the lithium metal anode and decreasing detrimental side reactions. During 1500 cycles at the current density of 1 mA cm−2, the CuO/Cu3N foam@Li symmetric cell displays an exceptionally low polarization, demonstrating its superior transmission capability of Li+ ions. In addition, it exhibits excellent structure stability and electrochemical performance, maintaining stable cycles of over 500 h at high current density and capacity of 5 mA cm−2 and 5 mAh cm−2. Ultimately, the outstanding performance of the full cell consists of LFP and CuO/Cu3N foam@Li provides more evidence of potential and usefulness of CuO/Cu3N foam for high-energy LMBs.

Fig. 1 a schematically depicts the preparation procedure for CuO/Cu3N foam. Cu foam was soaked in a heated mixed solution of NaOH/(NH4)2S2O8, and the surface layer was further treated with urea as a nitrogen source to obtain CuO/Cu3N foam. The color of Cu foam changed significantly after treatment (Figure S1 , Supporting Information). Fig. 1 b displays the cleaned Cu foam, which has a flat surface and an obvious grain pattern. The CuO foam oxidized with a mixed solution has a dense fibrous secondary structure, which replaces the smooth grain structure on the surface, significantly increasing the specific surface area (Fig. 1 c). The surface morphology of CuO/Cu3N foam treated with high-temperature nitriding is shown in Fig. 1 d. This is due to the fact that the partial reduction of CuO that occurs at high temperatures weakens the fiber structure even in an Ar environment. Concurrently, localized strain is introduced by the addition of nitrogen to the lattice to generate Cu3N, which causes the thin fibers to shatter brittlely. Structural instability is exacerbated by the inadequate nitridation caused by the inhomogeneous release of degraded urea. Although the fibrous secondary structure formed by the oxidation treatment has collapsed, the material still essentially has a high specific surface area and a fibrous structure, allowing the CuO/Cu3N foam current collector to maintain its high electrochemical performance. It is evident from the cross-sectional scanning electron microscope (SEM) images and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) images of CuO/Cu3N foam that the N and O elements are dispersed uniformly throughout the grid structure (Fig. 1 e-g). CuO and Cu3N has been successfully created on the surface of the Cu foam structure and uniformly distributed, as shown by the even distribution of O and N elements in the single CuO/Cu3N fiber (Figure S2 , Supporting Information). As can be seen, there is still some O element remnant in the CuO/Cu3N foam, which indicates that the CuO was not completely nitrided inside, as further X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern has shown.

The samples underwent XRD testing to determine the phase composition in order to confirm the existence of oxidized product of Cu foam (Figure S3 , Supporting Information). The (-110), (002), (111), and (200) peaks of CuO were discovered at 2θ of 32.5°, 35.5°, 38.6°, and 38.8° in the XRD pattern of CuO foam, respectively, suggesting that CuO was successfully synthesized. The (100), (110), (111), and (200) peaks of Cu3N can be found in the XRD spectrum of the high-temperature nitrided CuO/Cu3N foam at 2θ of 23.3°, 33.2°, 40.8°, and 47.6°, respectively, which indicates that Cu3N was obtained effectively, while the XRD spectrum also shows the appearance of weak CuO peaks (Fig. 1 h). During the lithium deposition, the heterostructure made up of the lithophilic Cu3N and CuO is more likely to exert its lithophilicity, which is more favorable to the deposition of lithium metal inside the CuO/Cu3N foam.

XPS characterization of the Cu 2p spectra for the three prepared foams reveals that compared to the copper foam, the CuO foam shows characteristic Cu2+ peaks at 942.84 eV along with satellite peaks, corresponding to the formation of CuO (Figure S4 , Supporting Information) [30]. In contrast, the CuO/Cu3N foam exhibits disappearance of the Cu2+ satellite peaks and reduced intensity of the main characteristic peaks, with the Cu 2p3/2 signal shifting (933.60 eV) from the Cu0 position observed in the copper foam (931.39 eV) [31]. These changes are attributed to the presence of Cu+ species and indicate that most CuO has been converted through nitridation, confirming the successful preparation of CuO/Cu3N foam.[32]

By using density functional theory (DFT) simulation, the binding energies of lithium on different matrices were determined in order to investigate the impact of CuO and Cu3N surface layers on the nucleation and subsequent deposition behavior of Li ( Fig. 2 a, b). The bare Cu foam shows a relatively weak binding energy (-0.046 eV), suggesting the likelihood of deleterious dendritic development and thermodynamically unfavorable circumstances for Li nucleation. CuO and Cu3N, on the other hand, have binding energies to Li+ ions of −0.080 eV and −0.123 eV, respectively. CuO and Cu3N surface layers, which are consistently dispersed, have improved lithophilicity. This ensures uniform and fast behavior of Li deposition, significantly lowering the nucleation barrier and enhancing reaction kinetics. The fibrous secondary structure guarantees stable and long-term electrode functioning by enhancing the active sites of Li deposition and reducing notable volume variations during plating/stripping.

Foam current collectors were subjected to XPS testing to examine the composition of surface following lithium deposits. The results of DFT simulation are validated by the XPS spectra of O 1 s and N 1 s in Fig. 2 c, d, which show a marked increase in the relative contents of Li2O and Li3N on the CuO/Cu3N foam surface, suggesting that the heterogeneous SEI was successfully loaded on the CuO/Cu3N foam surface. The inorganic LixNOy compounds formed on the surface of the anode by the decomposition of a small amount of LiTFSI in the electrolyte during lithium deposition also contribute to the formation of robust SEI. Even though CuO foam has a Li2O-rich SEI, it is still poor that the ability of single Li2O to transport lithium ions relatively. As a result, there will be an uneven lithium deposition on the surface of CuO foam and more active lithium will be consumed, leading to a shortened cycle life of the cells. According to Figure S5 (Supporting Information), the XPS spectra of C 1 s and Li 1 s reveal that the SEI of Cu foam is mainly composed of alkyl lithium (ROCO2Li) created by the reaction of electrolyte with lithium and other organic components decomposed by electrolyte [33], which decreases the mechanical strength of the surface of electrode. The activation energy needed for lithium deposition on Cu foam is larger due to the lack of a lithophilic surface layer and SEI of high ionic conductivity. Lithium is more likely to nucleate on the protrusions of surface as a result of the tip effect, which can lead to the dendritic development and drastic volume change. Rapid and consistent dispersion of Li+ ions is thus made possible by the generation of Li2O and Li3N riched SEI from the lithophilic surface layer in conjunction with the 3D framework [34–36]. This method make LMBs have steady and prolonged cycle performance, particularly at high current densities, by efficiently resolving issues with dendritic growth, dead Li and volume expansion (Fig. 2 e).

When nucleating on Cu, lithium must overcome the nucleation barrier first at which point the electrode potential drops sharply below 0 V (vs. Li+/Li), i.e., nucleation overpotential, where the spike in the capacity-voltage curve indicates the nucleation process [37]. After then, Li+ ions develop on the existing lithium nuclei, which requires a lower energy barrier for lithium deposition than during the nucleation stage, exhibiting smooth curve and tiny overpotential [38]. Lithium goes through two processes when it is deposited on CuO and CuO/Cu3N foams, that is chemical reaction and physical nucleation. Initially, lithium will form Li2O and Li3N in situ on the surface of CuO and CuO/Cu3N foams, respectively. As the reaction proceeds, lithium diffuses to the surface of foam to form clusters, and after reaching a critical size, starts to nucleate [39]. CuO and Cu3N have larger binding energies with Li than Cu does, which can lower the nucleation barrier of lithium significantly. Due to their superior ionic conductivity, Li2O and Li3N can speed the kinetics of Li+ ion transport during deposition, allowing lithium metal to nucleate uniformly on the surface of the current collector and preventing the formation of lithium dendrites [40,41].

It is essential to control the thickness of surface layer since it has an impact on the final performance of Cu foam. The thickness of the oxide layer and the ultimate nitride layer is correlated, with the time of oxidation being the primary parameter that controls the latter. As demonstrated in Figure S6 (Supporting Information), the capacity of the lithium required to convert CuO to Li2O increases with the expanding of the oxidation time from 5 to 40 min due to the chemical reaction of lithium nucleation. This implies that increasing the oxidation time thickens the oxide layer, suggesting that it is possible to control the thickness of oxide layer through oxidation time. Furthermore, the oxidized foam exhibits a smaller lithium nucleation overpotential or even no overpotential, as compared to the Cu foam, indicating that lithium deposition can be carried out continuously after the convertion of CuO to Li2O without getting over a higher nucleation barrier. The voltage-capacity curves of CuO foams oxidized for 5–40 min are displayed in Figure S7 (Supporting Information), at 5th, 10th, and 30th cycles, respectively. It is clear that the CuO foam oxidized for 20 min maintains the highest capacity and has a good capacity retention rate in different cycle number. This could be attributed to the thicker oxide layers which produced by longer oxidation times. Thicker SEI is formed during the chemical reaction of nucleation by consuming more lithium, and the subsequent deposition of lithium through the SEI requires more activation energy, which leads to slow lithium transport and rapid capacity decay. If the oxidation duration is too short, a lithium deposition produces thin and unstable SEI that is easily destroyed during cycling and the active lithium inside will be exposed, which leads to the constant side reactions with the electrolyte. Consequently, the CuO foam oxidized for 20 min is ultimately chosen for the subsequent nitriding.

It is challenging to fully utilize the 3D structure since lithium tends to deposit on the top of the 3D current collector. With different capacities of deposition, various electrodes were investigated through SEM to examine their surfaces and macroscopic features. Lithium deposits on the surface of Cu foam in an uneven distribution when the deposition capacity is only 1 mAh cm−2, as shown in Figure S8 and S9 (Supporting Information). In certain areas of the surface of Cu foam, lithium deposits are dense, while in other areas they are loose, indicating a irregular deposition. The reason is that the slow deposition kinetics of lithium on Cu with poor lithophilicity result in the deposition of lithium at the upper layer of the 3D frame and uneven lithium deposition is caused by a high local current density. Due to the larger specific surface area and the improved lithophilicity, lithium can be deposited along the 3D skeleton of CuO foam and CuO/Cu3N foam rather than on the top of the current collector (Figure S10 and S11 , Supporting Information). The heterogeneous layer that is formed on the surface of the CuO/Cu3N foam has stronger lithophilicity than single CuO or Cu3N, which can guide the lithium to deposit more evenly inside the foam during lithium plating/stripping.

To enable a more intuitive observation of the impact of the surface layer on the behavior of lithium deposition on current collectors, the capacity for lithium deposition has been increased (Figure S12 , Supporting Information). The surface morphology of the current collectors after the deposition of large quantities of lithium varies greatly. A large number of loose lithium in various forms can be seen on the surface of Cu foam@Li, and CuO foam@Li also shows uneven lithium deposition, while the surface of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li is more dense and flat. The cross-sectional SEM image of lithium electrodeposited on Cu foam demonstrates the massive deposits of lithium at the top and the absence of lithium filling in the spaces at the bottom. It is apparent that the lithium is densely packed in the porous structure of CuO/Cu3N foam following lithium deposition, as opposed to that of Cu and CuO foam, suggesting that the space utilization has been greatly increased. As the capacity of deposition increases, lithium metal nucleates and grows along the secondary fiber structure and then uniformly fills the voids of foam structure, keeping the surface of CuO/Cu3N foam dense and smooth. The robust structure of Li2O/Li3N-rich SEI and highly lithophilic framework accomplish uniform deposition and dendrite-free surface, while the poor lithophilicity of Cu foam causes uneven deposition with substantial voids and the generation of dead lithium.

Asymmetric cells were constructed to assess the plating/stripping behaviors of the current collectors in order to investigate the reversibility and stability of CuO/Cu3N foam in electrolyte. Initially, the nucleation overpotential of lithium on the current collectors at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 was examined ( Fig. 3 a). The deposition process that starts with physical nucleation is chosen for comparison since the deposition of lithium on CuO foam and CuO/Cu3N foam have a process of chemical reaction first. There is a low nucleation overpotential of CuO/Cu3N foam on the deposition curve, which is attributed to the stable foam matrix with a Li2O and Li3N riched SEI, suggesting that the polarization during lithium plating is greatly suppressed. It implies that the dendrite formation and related safety issues are essentially inhibited by the capacity of CuO/Cu3N foam to expedite the migration of Li ions and effectively accommodate deposited lithium. On the other hand, there is a nucleation of tiny new crystals due to the larger nucleation overpotential of Li on Cu foam, which causes the uneven deposition. A coulombic efficiency analysis was performed, which the current collector was subjected to a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2, with a cut-off voltage of 1 V. CuO/Cu3N foam has an average coulombic efficiency of 89.3 % after 200 cycles, with the corresponding voltage-capacity curve showing minimal capacity loss (Fig. 3 b, c). The secondary structure of nitrogen-rich fibers grown on the Cu foam surface greatly enhance the specific surface area and active sites of the current collector. And the Li2O/Li3N SEI gradually stabilizes with cycling, guiding a uniform deposition of lithium. CuO/Cu3N foam dramatically lowers the local current density and extends the cycle life of cells by minimizing the hazardous side reactions of electrode-electrolyte interface and the consumption of active lithium, as demonstrated by the steady coulombic efficiency. CuO foam and Cu foam, on the other hand, show fluctuating coulombic efficiency and rapid decay of capacity, indicating that the continuous side reactions seriously impair the cycling stability (Figure S13 , Supporting Information).

A methodical comparison was made between the galvanostatic plating/stripping behavior of various electrodes at varying current densities and deposition capacities. Fig. 3 d shows the cycling curves of symmetric cells with CuO/Cu3N foams, CuO foams, and Cu foams, each of the electrode having a pre-lithiation deposition capacity of 40 mAh cm−2. The CuO/Cu3N foam@Li symmetric cell exhibits better cycling performance that can be stably cycled for over 1500 h at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. The lithophilic 3D framework and high ion conductivity of SEI rich in Li2O/Li3N are responsible for the low polarization and stable voltage curve. Moreover, the smooth distribution of the voltage curve at polarity flip indicates that the enhanced SEI improves the transport kinetics of lithium ions. These properties work together to promote uniform lithium deposition and low interface resistance. Unfortunately, the Cu foam@Li symmetric cell exhibits serious voltage fluctuations due to the side reactions at the electrode-electrolyte interface with a poor cycling ability of fewer than 100 h. And the CuO foam@Li symmetric cell is also unable to accomplish long-term steady cycling, with a maximum cycle life of 200 h. To thoroughly test the performance of Li2O/Li3N SEI and ensure that the lithium metal is able to plating and stripping from the bottom of 3D structure with each cycle, the capacity of lithium plating is lowered to 15 mAh cm−2. With the extended cycles, the polarization voltage of low loaded CuO/Cu3N foam@Li symmetric cell rises from approximately 0.020 V to 0.045 V. And the low loaded CuO/Cu3N foam@Li symmetric cell exhibits a higher average polarization voltage than that of high loaded cell during the whole cycling ‎(Figure S14 ， Supporting Information). This is because CuO/Cu3N foam@Li with fewer deposits has relatively less active lithium that can plating and stripping at each cycle on the surface. And most of the lithium stored inside the foam requires higher energy to strip to the counter electrode, raising the polarization voltage, but the utilization of lithium increases. The low loaded symmetric cell of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li||CuO/Cu3N foam@Li can also be stably cycled for over 800 h, which still shows a more excellent cycling performance than that of CuO foam and Cu foam, suggesting that the Li2O/Li3N SEI exhibits a good cycling stability. To further evaluate the performance of the symmetric cells under extreme conditions, tests were carried out at a high current density of 5 mA cm−2 and a high capacity of 5 mAh cm−2 with a lithium plating capacity of 40 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 3 e). The CuO foam@Li and Cu foam@Li symmetric cell fail quickly at the start of the cycle without a stable cycle period, suggesting the poor electrode-electrolyte interface exacerbates adverse responses and uneven deposition of lithium. In contrast, the CuO/Cu3N foam@Li symmetric cell exhibits excellent cycling capacity, with a stable cycling performance of more than 500 h. The 3D structure of CuO/Cu3N foam is able to accommodate lithium deposits in place effectively, which alleviates the mechanical stress brought on by volume variations and maintains structural integrity during lithium plating/stripping. The highly lithophilic CuO/Cu3N surface layer effectively reduces the nucleation overpotential of lithium and ensures the stability of the electrode structure. Lithium deposition also results in the formation of Li2O/Li3N riched SEI, which further prevents side reactions and dendritic development. The extended cycling life of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li cell at high current density and capacity is ensured by the synergistic effect of these measures.

Then the rate capabilities of the various electrodes were examined by increasing the current density and capacity simultaneously (Fig. 3 f). The CuO/Cu3N foam@Li displays a lower polarization and a more stable voltage profile across all the current densities and capacities. It can also revert to the low polarization when reducing from high current density and capacity of 5 mA cm−2 and 5 mAh cm−2 to 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2. Whereas when the current density and the capacity are increased to 2 mA cm−2 and 2 mAh cm−2, the CuO foam@Li and Cu foam@Li cannot even finish the cycling because of the poor electrode-electrolyte interfaces, which further highlights the superiority of the plating/stripping ability of CuO/Cu3N foam. Then the exchange current densities of symmetric cells with various current collectors with plated lithium were examined in order to comprehend the reaction kinetics of the Li plating/stripping and the capacity of ion transfer. The exchange current density of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li (2.92 mA cm−2) is nearly 6 times that of Cu foam@Li (0.46 mA cm−2) and 3 times larger than that of CuO foam@Li (0.74 mA cm−2), as demonstrated by the Tafel plot in Fig. 3 g, which suggests that Li2O/Li3N-rich SEI accelerates the interfacial transfer kinetics considerably.

Furthermore, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of symmetric cells before and after 10 cycles were compared (Figure S15 , Supporting Information). CuO/Cu3N foam@Li has the lowest impedance before cycling due to its more lithophilic surface layer, which can significantly enhance the electrochemical performance of cells and homogenize the deposited lithium, leading to a higher ion mobility and transport efficiency of Li+ ions that plated on the electrode through SEI under the same conditions. After 10 cycles, the interfacial impedances of all the three types of symmetric cells significantly decrease, signifying the creation of stable SEI and ion transport channels during cycling. As seen by the relatively small variation in the impedance of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li before and after cycling, the electrode maintains constant ion diffusion barrier and reaction kinetics throughout the cycling.

The surface morphologies of the electrodes of symmetric cells were examined after 10 cycles at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 and a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 in order to assess the reversibility of plating/stripping of various anodes. The Cu foam@Li surface is loose and disorganized, with many dendrites and dead Li easily apparent, according to the SEM images in Fig. 4 a, b. The thick surface of the deposited lithium and the interior of the hardly filled foam structure are also clearly observed in the cross-sectional SEM image (Fig. 4 c). The low electrochemical stability and reversibility of Cu foam is in line with this observation. Li2O-rich SEI significantly improves the surface morphology of CuO foam@Li, compared with Cu foam@Li (Fig. 4 d, e). Nonetheless, the difference of morphology and numerous large pores on the surface are still the results of uneven deposition of lithium. It is insufficient for single Li2O to efficiently accelerate the transport of Li+ ions, and the internal structure is not used to its full potential, causing the slow reaction kinetics and relatively low coulombic efficiency (Fig. 4 f). CuO/Cu3N foam@Li, on the other hand, maintains a flat, uniform, and denser surface (Fig. 4 g, h) with a improved utilization of the foam structure (Fig. 4 i), as a result of the decreased nucleation overpotential and local current density, demonstrating the outstanding reversibility and stability of the structure.

In order to understand the accelerated interfacial dynamics, XPS was utilized to identify the changes in the composition and relative content of SEI in the three electrodes after cycling. Electronically insulated SEI is essential to the lithium transport dynamics of the interface. The N 1 s spectra indicate a strong contrast between CuO/Cu3N foam@Li and Cu foam@Li (Fig. 4 j). CuO/Cu3N foam@Li exhibits stronger signals of nitrogenous compounds because of the pre-formed Li3N surface layer and the breakdown of TFSI- in the electrolyte during cycling, while the Cu foam@Li shows a significant LiTFSI signal and N-SOx, an incomplete decomposition product of TFSI-. It has long been believed that SEI of compounds containing nitrogen helps to speed up interfacial diffusion of Li+ ions [41,42]. The intensity of C-O and Li2O of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li and CuO foam@Li does not remarkably change before and after cycling, according to the O 1 s spectra, and the CuO/Cu3N foam@Li still contains a large amount of Li2O after cycling (Fig. 4 k). There is no significant change in the SEI content of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li, revealing the stability and durability of inorganic-rich SEI and the important role that Li2O/Li3N heterogeneous SEI plays in interfacial transport dynamics. However, the O 1 s spectrum of Cu foam@Li shows a notable rise in the component content. Additionally, the C 1 s and Li 1 s spectra demonstrate that the unstable and brittle SEI of Cu foam@Li is destroyed continuously during cycling, causing that the fresh lithium inside is constantly exposed to contact and react with the electrolyte, which results in a sharp increase in the content of Li2O and ROCO2Li. (Figure S16 , Supporting Information).

The COMSOL simulation further illustrates the reasons for the various characteristics of electrodes. The protrusions in the model represent the irregular surface structure of copper foam, and the current density distribution on the surface of different anodes is simulated, based on the difference between the exchange current density obtained from the experiment and the lithium loving material on the surface of foam, the current density distribution. Induced by the tip effect, the current tends to build in the uneven convex area on the Cu foam@Li, which exacerbates the aggregation of Li+ ions on the tip and leads to rapid dendrite formation, highlighting the unsuitability of Cu foam for uniform Li deposition and long-term stability (Fig. 4 l). Similarly, the CuO foam@Li still faces the large local current density even though a lithophilic layer has formed on the surface (Fig. 4 m). But it is possible to achieve the dispersion of local current density for CuO/Cu3N foam@Li by the rapid migration of Li+ ions (Fig. 4 n). Furthermore, the increased utilization of the 3D structure of current collector, reduces the volume fluctuation significantly during lithium plating and stripping, laying the foundation for superior electrochemical performance and extended cycle life of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li.

Full cells of the three types of foam anodes with lithium capacity of 30 mAh cm−2 and LiFePO4 (LFP) cathodes were assembled to evaluate the potential of practical application. When the cathode loading is 2.8 mg cm−2 and the charge-discharge rate is 1 C (1 C = 170 mA g−1), the full cell of Cu foam@Li exhibits the lowest capacity retention rate after few cycles due to the continual side reaction between the lithium metal and the electrolyte caused by the unstable interface, resulting in the continuous consumption of active lithium ( Fig. 5 a). Corresponding with the test results of half cell, the CuO foam@Li||LFP full cell also shows a sharp decline in coulombic efficiency after 220 cycles, eventually fails at 280 cycles. It is likely ascribed to the relatively low kinetics of interfacial ion transport and the accumulation of side reaction products. However, the full cell of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li||LFP offers a high capacity retention rate of more than 78 % and a steady cycling for more than 350 h. It can be attributed to the stable and robust SEI, which prevents the exposure of active lithium and unfavorable side reactions, exhibiting a useful and persistent protective effect. Furthermore, compared to Cu foam@Li, the charge-discharge curves of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li is smoother with a smaller voltage hysteresis. And after 300 cycles, it still remains a specific capacity of about 120 mAh g−1, suggesting the significant improvement of stability and kinetics of reaction of full cell (Fig. 5 b-d). The performances of fast charging and discharging of the full cells were investigated by rate test (Fig. 5 e). As the rate rises, the capacity of Cu and CuO foam@Li||LFP exhibits a sharp decline. The capacity of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li||LFP always higher than that of Cu and CuO foam when the rate is increased from 0.5 C to 5 C gradually, which can be returned to 120 mAh g−1 when the rate is restored to 1 C. This confirms that Li2O/Li3N SEI can improve the kinetics of Li+ ion diffusion and promote the electrochemical performance.

Furthermore, full cells with NCM811 cathodes were assembled to investigate the compatibility of the three types of electrodes for high-voltage cathodes. Similarly, the CuO/Cu3N foam@Li||NCM811 full cell also exhibits better electrochemical performance at 1 C (1 C = 200 mAh g−1), comparing with the full cells with CuO foam@Li and Cu foam@Li, and the charge-discharge curves demonstrate that the polarization voltage of the full cell with CuO/Cu3N foam@Li is lower than that of Cu foam@Li (Fig. 5 f and Figure S17 , Supporting Information). The performance comparison with other literature data in Fig. 5 g further emphasizes the superiority of CuO/Cu3N foams [15,17,43–49]. The excellent cycling and rate performance of CuO/Cu3N foam@Li anode in various full cells verify that the lithophilic layer and Li2O/Li3N-rich SEI play an important role in directing uniform lithium deposition and preventing the growth of lithium dendrites during long-term cycling.

Taking advantage of the 3D frame structure, Cu foams were simply treated by using a mixed solution and nitriding at high temperature in turn, and finally Cu foams with homogeneous surface loading of CuO/Cu3N were prepared. During lithium deposition, the lithophilic CuO/Cu3N can be reduced to the robust Li2O/Li3N SEI, improving the kinetics of lithium transportation and lowering the local current density effictively. Consequently, the CuO/Cu3N@Li symmetric cell showed a even deposition of Li and cycled steadily for over 1500 h at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2, which can even cycle for 500 h at a high current density and capacity of 5 mA cm−2 and 5 mAh cm−2, respectively. The full cell with LFP cathode can be cycled for more than 350 h at 1 C, with a high capacity retention of more than 78 %. The performance of Cu foam modified by simple process has been greatly improved, which provides a new scheme and idea for the modification of 3D current collector for highly stable LMBs.

Keqi Zhou: Visualization, Validation, Resources. Tang Wenhao: Methodology, Investigation. Ruiping Liu: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization. Yanlin Zhang: Writing – original draft, Visualization, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. Shun Yao: Software, Investigation, Formal analysis. Xinquan Zhang: Writing – original draft, Visualization, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation.
